SPECIAL CALLED SCHOOL BOARD MEETING

The School Board of Isle of Wight County will hold a Special Called Meeting on Monday, August 3, 2020, at 9:00am in the Cafeteria of Westside Elementary School, 800 West Main Street, Smithfield, VA 23430.

The School Board intends to take a vote to rescind the vote made at the July 30, 2020 School Board meeting regarding the adopted school reopening plan. Specifically, the previously adopted plan calls for the reopening of elementary and middle schools with parent choice of either 100 percent virtual for the semester or an AB hybrid model, and for the reopening of the high school with parent choice of either 100 percent virtual for the semester or in a total remote environment for nine weeks before revisiting in-person options at the end of the nine weeks.



Guests should enter through the front door of the building and face coverings are required. The meeting will be streamed live on the IWCS Facebook page and YouTube channel.

Students from Westside Elementary School were recently awarded the top three spots in the Visual Arts division of the Virginia Peninsula Holocaust Art Contest and the top spot in the Writing division.

Students placing in the Middle School Visual Arts category include: Graham Thomas—First place, Alyze Pizarro—Second place, and Elizabeth Smith—Third Place. Other finalists were Nia Boyd and Phetchinda Mady. In the Middle School Writing Division, Campbell Lowery received First place, with Lily Lufkin and Terrance Booker selected as finalists. The prompt asked participants to write a dialogue where they are the grandchild of a Holocaust survivor. In her winning entry, Lowery described a student interviewing her great grandmother, Bubbe, for a school project. The short story explains Bubbe’s escape from the Holocaust as a young child.

Learn more about the competition, see all the winning artwork and read the winning writing entry in it's entirety on the IWCS website at www.iwcs.k12.va.us

Smithfield High School JROTC Cadet Barrett Ferguson Recognized in VSSAR State Essay Competition

Smithfield High School Army JROTC Cadet Barrett Ferguson placed first in the Richmond Chapter and third in Virginia in the Virginia Society Sons of the American Revolution (VSSAR) Enhanced Cadet Competition. Ferguson’s essay and application was selected from 27 other schools competing in the Richmond Chapter Region. His regional win qualified him for state competition, where he placed third. His essay, “How JROTC has prepared me to be a better citizen of the United States of America,” spoke to the curricula and application of that curricula he learned through his five semesters of taking JROTC. His essay also addressed how the values of the program mirrored the values he was being taught at home.
Peter Davenport, the VSSAR President, and Dennis Peterson, the VSSAR Richmond Chapter President, presented Barrett his medal, certificate, and cash award at a March luncheon for the state-level winners.

Back in March, Mr. and Mrs. Rodriguez visited their granddaughter's class at Hardy Elementary School to share information with them about rainforests as part of their study of ecology. The class found that the their home land of Colombia has the largest rainforest--the Serrania del Chiribiquete.

The Rodriguezes brought treats for the students and coloring pages with rainforest animals labeled in English and Spanish. He went through the animal names with the students reading them in Spanish while the teacher, Mrs. Hansley, read them in English. Mr. Rodriguez read a book to the class titled Step Inside the Rainforest. He also read a book titled Tortillas and Lullabies which is written in English and Spanish. Mrs. Hansley read the parts in English and he read in Spanish.

Mr. Rodriguez has read to the class before and enjoys sharing Spanish speaking skills with the students.

We have had several community members and organizations ask how they can help the school division while school is closed. And for that we say Thank You!

Right now, we have enough help with meal distribution.

What you can do, however, is check with families in your neighborhood, organizations, or church and see if their children are getting meals. If not, and you are able to, please stop by one of our meal distribution sites and pick up meals for those children we aren't reaching. Isle of Wight County is large geographically, and even with numerous distribution sites, we know we have students who may not be getting meals that they need.

It's times like this that we have to come together as a community and look out for our neighbors. We live in a caring community--a compassionate community--and we know that working together is the only way we can make it through these unprecedented times. ♥️

This afternoon, Governor Northam announced the closing of all schools across Virginia from Monday, March 16, through Friday, March 27. On Monday, March 16, staff will be reporting to schools to develop packets and plans for continuity of instruction during the two weeks schools are closed. We will notify parents Monday regarding the plan for distribution of instructional materials.

In addition, we are working on a plan for meal distribution. Our goal is to provide grab and go breakfast and lunches at designated locations throughout the county. Information on the specific locations will also be shared with families on Monday.

A waiver process is in place through the Virginia Department of Education for makeup days for emergencies. We will be requesting a waiver and, at this point, spring break is not affected.

As a reminder, with the closure of schools, all school activities are canceled, including athletics, club meetings, and PTA events.

At this point, there is no criteria regarding the reopening of schools. We will pass along information as it becomes available.

Hardy Elementary Students Qualify for State Archery Tournament

The Hardy Elementary School Archery Team’s success in the Regional Archery Tournament in Newport News, VA has qualified them to compete at the state level. The state tournament will be held in Doswell, VA on March 14, 2020.

Hardy implemented the National Archery in Schools Program (NASP) during the fall of 2018. The program focuses on fourth through twelfth graders and is designed to improve education performance. Michael Cooke, the physical education teacher at Hardy Elementary, serves as the coach of the program. All fourth graders are exposed to archery through their physical education class. Students interested in the archery team stay after school for additional practice time.

“Having been a NASP Instructor since 2007, I have seen the positive impact it has on students,” said Cooke. “It gives them a sense of belonging. It provides them a reason to want to come to school and be successful.”

Hardy Elementary is the only school in Isle of Wight County currently offering an archery program for students.

Isle of Wight County Schools (IWCS) was one of four school divisions recognized in the 2019 Virginia School Boards Association’s (VSBA) Exhibition of School Architecture. Winning projects were selected from 11 entries submitted by 6 architectural firms in the areas of new construction, renovation and adaptive use of existing space. The division was recognized with the Silver Design Award for Career and Technology Education (CTE) renovations at Smithfield High School and Windsor High School. The renovations included spaces for Cosmetology, Nursing, Culinary Arts, Manufacturing, and Engineering, along with a Mechatronics Lab, a MakerSpace, and a student-run restaurant. The project, completed by RRMM Architects, was selected from 11 entries submitted by 6 architectural firms in the areas of new construction, renovation and adaptive use of existing space. IWCS was recognized at the opening general session of the VSBA Annual Convention recently held in Williamsburg, VA.

Elise Ring reached out to Hardy Elementary for her girl scout project this year. She shared a presentation with the students on litter in order to raise awareness about the problem. She also explained to the students the impact litter has on the environment and gave them examples of what they could do to help.

After the presentation, DeAnna Lawrence, the Sanitation Supervisor with Isle of Wight County Solid Waste, provided supplies to all the students so they could do their part to help keep Hardy Elementary free from litter.

Over the summer, our student information system, PowerSchool, went through a significant upgrade. One of the changes affected how contact information (phone numbers, email addresses) is stored in PowerSchool, which, in turn, impacted how Connect 5 pulls this information.

We have been made aware that some of our families may not be receiving emails to primary, or multiple, email addresses, or possibly calls to certain numbers.

These issues can be resolved by setting up a Parent Portal Account in Connect 5. To do this, you will need your child's school ID number to complete the process. Just follow the detailed steps on the document using the link below. If you previously created an account, it's possible that you need to associate your child to the account, or you may need to update your contact information. The document will walk you through those steps as well. If you have any issues creating or updating your account, please contact your child's school.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/18SbvtXgZuu22TQO9gzI7CWbhw3mK_UB1/view

Students in Mrs. Hansley's class at Hardy Elementary had the pleasure of listening to a guest reader share a story with them in Spanish. Mr. Rodriguez is the grandfather of one of the students and is from the country of Colombia. The story was called, Tripping Tadpole. Mrs. Hansley read the story in English and Mr. Rodriguez read the story in Spanish.

Afterwards, he taught the students how to say good morning, good afternoon and good evening in Spanish.

Mr. Rodriguez brought copies of the story and treat bags for all of the students to take home.

Thank you Mr. Rodriguez for sharing with the students at Hardy Elementary and helping them celebrate Spanish History Month.

Governor Ralph Northam awarded $6 million in School Security Equipment Grants to protect students and teachers in 340 schools and 70 school divisions. Isle of Wight County Schools will receive $41,122 to be used for security improvements at both Hardy Elementary and Westside Elementary schools. The grants will pay for security cameras upgrades at both locations and security door hardware at Hardy.

Since the program began in 2013, IWCS has received over $412,000 which has funded security improvements at all division elementary schools and both high schools.

“The safety of our students is always our top priority,” said Superintendent Jim Thornton. “This funding from the state will help ensure that we are continuing to provide our students and staff with a secure learning environment.”
